verses.text: Now I do not want you to be unaware, brothers, that our ancestors were all under the cloud, and all passed through the sea.
verses.comment: Paul refers to the Exodus, connecting the Israelites' journey with Christian baptism as a spiritual precursor. The 'cloud' symbolizes God's presence and guidance (see also Exod. 13:21-22).

verses.text: They were all baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea.
verses.comment: Paul uses 'baptized into Moses' as a type—a foreshadowing—of Christian baptism, drawing a parallel between Moses' leadership and Christ's (see Rom. 6:3-4 for similar language).

verses.text: All ate the same spiritual food,
verses.comment: The 'spiritual food' refers to the manna from heaven, a supernatural provision that foreshadows the true bread from heaven (see John 6:31-35).

verses.text: and all drank the same spiritual drink. For they drank from the spiritual rock that followed them, and that rock was Christ.
verses.comment: Paul identifies Christ as present with Israel, revealing a high Christology—the preexistence of Jesus. The rock is a type of Christ, the true source of living water (see John 7:37-38).

verses.text: Nevertheless, with most of them, God was not pleased, for their bodies were scattered in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Paul warns that participation in spiritual blessings is no guarantee of salvation if there is disobedience. The fate of the Israelites serves as a sobering example.

verses.text: Now these things happened as examples for us, so that we should not desire evil things as they did.
verses.comment: Old Testament events provide moral lessons for Christians. Paul draws a direct connection between the past and present community, urging moral vigilance.

verses.text: Do not be idolaters as some of them were; as it is written, 'The people sat down to eat and drink and rose up to play.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Exodus to show the danger of idolatry, stressing faithfulness in worship. Participation in solemn feasts must not be corrupted by idolatrous or immoral behavior.

verses.text: Nor let us commit sexual immorality as some of them did, and in one day twenty-three thousand fell.
verses.comment: Paul references the plague from Numbers 25, warning that God judges sin among His people (see also Jude 1:7).

verses.text: Nor let us test Christ, as some of them did, and were destroyed by serpents.
verses.comment: While the Old Testament texts mention testing 'the Lord,' Paul explicitly uses 'Christ,' underlining the unity of the Son with the Lord of Israel. The bronze serpent is a type that points to Christ's crucifixion (see John 3:14).

verses.text: Nor grumble, as some of them did, and were killed by the destroyer.
verses.comment: Paul warns against complaining, which led to destruction in Israel's history. The 'destroyer' references the angel of death from the Exodus events.

verses.text: Now these things happened to them as examples, and were written down for our instruction, on whom the end of the ages has come.
verses.comment: Paul asserts that history is meaningful for Christians, who are living in the era fulfilled by Christ and the Church.

verses.text: Therefore, let anyone who thinks he stands take heed lest he fall.
verses.comment: This verse underscores the necessity of humility and self-examination. Assurance must not give way to presumption.

verses.text: No temptation has overtaken you except what is common to man. But God is faithful, and he will not allow you to be tempted beyond what you can bear, but with the temptation will also provide the way out, so that you may be able to endure it.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes God's active role in providing help during temptation—a foundational truth for believers persevering in holiness.

verses.text: Therefore, my beloved, flee from idolatry.
verses.comment: Paul's exhortation points to the radical nature of conversion—a complete turning away from all worship not owed to the one true God.

verses.text: I speak as to sensible people; judge for yourselves what I say.
verses.comment: Paul appeals to reason, encouraging the Corinthians to discern spiritual truths intelligently.

verses.text: The cup of blessing that we bless, is it not a participation in the blood of Christ? The bread that we break, is it not a participation in the body of Christ?
verses.comment: Paul describes the Eucharist—with sober, literal language—as a real sharing in Christ's body and blood. This supports a high, sacramental view of communion (see John 6:53-56).

verses.text: Because there is one bread, we who are many are one body, for we all partake of the one bread.
verses.comment: Communion not only unites believers to Christ but to each other as one body. This underscores the unity of the Church through the one bread.

verses.text: Consider Israel according to the flesh: are not those who eat the sacrifices partners in the altar?
verses.comment: Paul parallels the shared sacrifices of Israel with Christian participation in the Eucharist—participating at the altar is an act of fellowship with God.

verses.text: What am I saying then? That food offered to idols is anything, or that an idol is anything?
verses.comment: Paul clarifies that idols have no real existence. This prepares for his teaching on the spiritual consequences of idolatrous acts.

verses.text: No, but what the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God. I do not want you to be partners with demons.
verses.comment: Idolatry is more than ignorance—it opens fellowship to evil spirits. Paul warns that the Lord tolerates no divided loyalty (see 2 Cor. 6:14-16).

verses.text: You cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You cannot share in the table of the Lord and the table of demons.
verses.comment: Table fellowship is exclusive—Christians are called to full devotion to the Lord, particularly in sacred celebrations.

verses.text: Or shall we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he?
verses.comment: God’s jealous love tolerates no rivals. Paul draws from Israel’s history to warn of the seriousness of provoking the Lord.

verses.text: "All things are lawful," but not all things are beneficial. "All things are lawful," but not all things build up.
verses.comment: Freedom in Christ is meant for edification, not self-indulgence. True liberty seeks the good of others and the building up of the community.

verses.text: Let no one seek his own good, but the good of his neighbor.
verses.comment: Christian charity demands selflessness and prioritizing the needs of others—an essential virtue for building up the body.

verses.text: Eat whatever is sold in the meat market without raising questions for conscience’ sake,
verses.comment: Believers are free to partake of food without scruples, affirming the goodness of God’s creation (compare 1 Tim. 4:4).

verses.text: for 'the earth is the Lord’s, and everything in it.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes from the Psalms to root his teaching in Scripture. All things ultimately belong to God (Ps. 24:1).

verses.text: If an unbeliever invites you to a meal and you want to go, eat whatever is set before you without raising questions for conscience’ sake.
verses.comment: Paul allows association and table fellowship with unbelievers so long as it does not compromise one’s conscience or faith.

verses.text: But if someone says to you, 'This was offered in sacrifice,' do not eat it, for the sake of the one who informed you, and for the sake of conscience—
verses.comment: Charity requires sensitivity to the conscience of others. Foregoing a liberty out of love is an important principle.

verses.text: I do not mean your own conscience, but that of the other. For why should my freedom be judged by another's conscience?
verses.comment: Paul insists on the balance between Christian freedom and love: liberty must always be considerate of others' spiritual wellbeing.

verses.text: If I take part with thankfulness, why am I denounced because of that for which I give thanks?
verses.comment: Participation with thanksgiving is commendable, yet even gratitude must be expressed in a way that does not cause others to stumble.

verses.text: So, whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do all to the glory of God.
verses.comment: Christian life is wholly oriented toward God’s glory, even in ordinary actions—a call to sanctity in everyday life.

verses.text: Give no offense to Jews, or to Greeks, or to the church of God,
verses.comment: Paul urges harmony and sensitivity within and outside the Christian community, reflecting the universality of the Gospel.

verses.text: just as I try to please everyone in everything, not seeking my own advantage, but that of many, so that they may be saved.
verses.comment: Paul models self-giving love, reflecting Christ’s own service, so that all may come to salvation through the unity and charity of the Church.
